questions.question: All of the following are contraindications of emetics except?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Parkinson's disease Explanation: Emetics are used in Parkinson’s disease Emetics induce vomiting. There are two drugs which are used to induce vomiting: Syrup of Ipecac (oral preparation) used in oral poisoning Apomorphine (given as injection- I/M or S/C) used in Parkinson’s disease (Option D) and erectile dysfunction (D2 agonist in the hypothalamus © I sexual activity) MECHANISM OF ACTION: Activates D2 receptors in the CTZ area. CONTRAINDICATIONS OF EMETICS IN POISONING : Corrosive poisoning (acids/ alkali) © I risk of perforation (Option A ruled out) CNS Stimulant (cocaine/ amphetamines) © I risk of seizures (Option C ruled out) Kerosene/petroleum poisoning © I risk of aspiration pneumonia Unconscious patient © I risk of aspiration pneumonia (Option B ruled out) opioid/morphine poisoning © emetics are not effective Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology- K.D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page 710 Apomorphine in erectile dysfunction

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman is just being shifted to the recovery room after an appendectomy. She feels nauseous. Which of the following is the most appropriate antiemetic for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Ondansetron Explanation: The drug of choice for postoperative nausea and vomiting is ondansetron. Classification of Antiemetics: Drug class Examples Uses Anticholinergic (M1 receptor) Hyoscine (scopolamine) DOC: motion sickness (Option D ruled out) Antihistamine (H1 receptor) Diphenhydramine Promethazine Cyclizine Meclizine Motion sickness 5HT3 antagonist Ondansetron Palonosetron Dalosetron Tropisetron Granisetron DOC: early onset chemo-induced vomiting DOC: Postoperative and postradiotherapy-induced vomiting (Option A) D2 blocker Metoclopramide Domperidone Mild to moderate vomiting GERD (Option C ruled out) NK1 inhibitor Aprepitant Fosaprepitant Netupitant Rolapitant DOC: late-onset chemotherapy-induced vomiting (Option B ruled out) Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology- K.D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page 711

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman has a history of nausea and vomiting, especially during her journeys. Which of the following would be the most appropriate drug for this patient to prevent the same during her next journey?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Hyoscine Explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of motion sickness, and the drug of choice for the same is hyoscine/ scopolamine, which is an anticholinergic (M1 receptor antagonist) Mechanism of action of anticholinergics and antihistaminic drugs : M1 receptor and H1 receptors are present in the inner ear labyrinth and they get activated when there is movement (during journeys) in the semi-circular canal © activate the vestibular nerve © stimulates CTZ in the brain © nausea and vomiting. M1 and H1 receptor blockers block this effect © I stimulation of the CTZ DRUGS USED FOR MOTION SICKNESS : Anticholinergics : Scopolamine Used as a transdermal patch. Use 4 to 5 hours before travel. Antihistamines : Diphenhydramine, Promethazine, and Cyclizine. Reference: Goodman and Gilman's- The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 863

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman is undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer. Despite taking her prescribed antiemetic medication, she experiences significant nausea and vomiting starting 24 hours after her chemotherapy sessions and lasting for several days. Which of the following is the 1st line drug used to relieve this patient’s chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Aprepitant Explanation: This patient is undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer, after 24 hours of therapy she complained of nausea and vomiting for several days. This suggests a delayed phase in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). The DOC for the same is an NK1 receptor antagonist (e.g; Aprepitant) Palonosetron can be used in the delayed phase by combining it with Dexamethasone. Fezolinetant is an NK3 receptor antagonist used to treat postmenopausal vasomotor syndrome (Option C).

questions.question: A 70-year-old man with Parkinson's disease has recently started treatment with levodopa. He reports experiencing significant nausea and vomiting since beginning the medication. Which of the following antiemetics is appropriate for this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Domperidone Explanation: The above scenario suggests levodopa-induced nausea and vomiting, and the drug of choice for the same is domperidone, which is a dopamine receptor (D2) antagonist. D2 receptor antagonists : Domperidone : Treats levodopa-induced nausea and vomiting. It does not cross the blood-brain barrier (vs metoclopramide) and hence does not interfere with the therapeutic effects of levodopa, but inhibits the D2 receptors on CTZ © decreasing vomiting. Metoclopramide : 5 HT4 agonist + D2 antagonist + raised Ach Crosses the blood-brain barrier and interferes with the therapeutic effects of levodopa, hence not preferred in levodopa-induced vomiting (Option A) Causes extrapyramidal side effects. Antipsychotics : Prochlorperazine (Option B)- DOC for violent vomiting Chlorpromazine (Option C) Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology- K.D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page 715

questions.question: A 64-year-old male patient with a history of lung cancer undergoing chemotherapy comes to the clinic with complaints of dizziness and red eyes for 4 days. He complained of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting 5 days ago, for which he was prescribed an antiemetic. Which of the following antiemetics would have led to his current presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Dranabinol Explanation: Dronabinol causes hypotension (leading to dizziness) and bloodshot eyes. Mechanism of action: CB1 agonist (Cannabinoid receptor) Uses: Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting Appetite stimulation. ADVERSE EFFECTS OF DRONABINOL : CNS effects : Exacerbation of mania, depression, and schizophrenia Dizziness Fatigue Cognitive impairment Cardiovascular effects : Tachycardia Hypotension or hypertension Conjunctival congestion Occasional abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting are potentially indicative of cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome. Drug Side effect Ondansetron Constipation, QT interval prolongation, headache (Option A ruled out) Metoclopramide Extrapyramidal side effects (by crossing the blood brain barrier) (Option B ruled out) Aprepitant QT interval prolongation (Option C ruled out) Reference: Goodman and Gilman's- The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 513 Side effects of Dronabinol

questions.question: A 25-year-old female comes to the clinic with complaints of vomiting associated with her migraine headache for the past 2 days. Which of the following can be effective in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Prochlorperazine Explanation: The drug of choice for migraine-induced vomiting is an antipsychotic such as prochlorperazine and chlorpromazine. Antipsychotics : They have antihistamine and anticholinergic properties and hence can be used in migraine-induced nausea and vomiting. They inhibit D2 receptors in CTZ, which is the mechanism behind preventing nausea and vomiting. They are also indicated in post-chemotherapy, postoperative nausea and vomiting and also in motion sickness. Lorazepam (Option A): The sedative, amnesic and anxiolytic properties of lorazepam help be used as an anticipatory medication in patients with terminal diseases. Nabilone ( Option B) which is a CB1 receptor agonist, is used prophylactically for post-chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Dexamethasone ( Option D) (Corticosteroids) reduce inflammation © reduce the inflammatory mediators like serotonin, dopamine, and substance P; mainly used in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Reference: Goodman and Gilman's- The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 1103 prochlorperazine in migraine-induced vomiting

questions.question: A 45-year-old female patient presents with mild to moderate pain in the upper right quadrant of her abdomen. Upon ultrasound examination, she is diagnosed with cholesterol gallstones. The physician prescribes ursodeoxycholic acid. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of this drug?

options.A: Decreases cholesterol absorption from the intestine
options.B: Decreases cholesterol synthesis in the liver

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Decreases cholesterol absorption from the intestine Explanation: Ursodeoxycholic acid acts by decreasing cholesterol absorption from the intestine. Ursodeoxycholic acid is a naturally occurring hydrophilic bile acid. When taken orally, it Alters relative concentrations of bile acids by reducing its absorption from the intestine Decreases biliary lipid secretion Reduces cholesterol content in bile, making it less likely to form gallstones It is also cytoprotective in cholestatic liver diseases like primary sclerosing cholangitis . Decreased cholesterol synthesis in the liver (Option B) is the mechanism of action of chenodeoxycholic acid and statins. Reference: Goodman and Gilman's- The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 1104

questions.question: A 45-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with symptoms of severe malabsorption following an extensive intestinal resection due to Crohn's disease. She has been diagnosed with short bowel syndrome and is currently receiving parenteral nutrition. Which of the following medications is not typically used to treat short bowel syndrome?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Ursodeoxycholic acid Explanation: Ursodeoxycholic acid is not used in short bowel syndrome but instead used in patients with biliary colic symptoms. SHORT BOWEL SYNDROME : Short bowel syndrome (SBS) is a difficult and frequently debilitating condition characterised by malabsorption and chronic diarrhoea. It occurs when a large portion of the intestine is removed. 3 new drugs for the treatment of short bowel syndrome : Growth hormone (Option A) : © increases production of IGF-1 © stimulates growth of bowel cells © enhances nutrient absorption. Octreotide (Option B): © decreases intestinal secretions © decreases malabsorptive diarrhoea, Teduglutide (Option D) : it is a recombinant GLP2 analogue © increases the production of IGF-1 © stimulates gut epithelial proliferation. Reference: Goodman and Gilman's- The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 1104 short bowel syndrome

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic abdominal pain and significant weight loss over the past year. He reports frequent, bulky and foul-smelling stools. His medical history is significant for alcohol abuse over the past 20 years. Laboratory investigations reveal normal LFT, and imaging studies show calcifications in the pancreas. Considering the patient's clinical presentation and medical history, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Lipase and trypsin Explanation: This patient with steatorrhoea due to chronic pancreatitis needs to be treated with pancreatic enzyme replacement. Indications for pancreatic enzyme replacement : Cystic fibrosis, Chronic pancreatitis, Post pancreatectomy. Drug used : Pancrelipase = Lipase + trypsin (lipase > trypsin) Reference: Goodman and Gilman's- The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 107
